docs.snippet: Kevin Durant’s consistency as a one-man team in Oklahoma City could lead to both a league title and most valuable player honors....
docs.lead_paragraph: Kevin Durant’s consistency as a one-man team in Oklahoma City could lead to both a league title and most valuable player honors.
docs.abstract: Off the Dribble blog; Kevin Durant’s consistency as a one-man team for Oklahoma City Thunder could lead to both a league title and most valuable player honors; he scored 25 points or more in 41 consecutive games; streak topped Michael Jordan’s 40 in 1985-86, though it fell well short of Wilt Chamberlain’s single-season record of 80 in 1961-62.

docs.snippet: It’s awfully difficult, if not downright impossible, to single out the Knicks’ worst defeats in a lost season. But here’s a sampling....
docs.lead_paragraph: It’s awfully difficult, if not downright impossible, to single out the Knicks’ worst defeats in a lost season. But here’s a sampling.
docs.abstract: Autopsy of New York Knicks season provides selection of defeats that range from humiliating blowouts to last-second fiascos, each offering a snapshot of how things went wrong.

headline.main: How Badly Did the Knicks Lose This Season? Let Us Count the Ways
headline.print_headline: How Badly Did the Knicks Lose This Season? Let Us Count the Ways

docs.snippet: After three straight postseason appearances, the Knicks will be done after the regular season, as the Hawks earned a 98-85 home victory over the Heat....
docs.lead_paragraph: After three straight postseason appearances, the Knicks will be done after the regular season, as the Hawks earned a 98-85 home victory over the Heat.
docs.abstract: NBA Roundup; Atlanta Hawks earn emphatic 98-85 victory over Miami Heat, to nail down the eighth and final playoff spot in the Eastern Conference; win ends New York Knicks hopes for playoff spot; other scores noted.

headline.main: Knicks’ Playoff Hopes End as Hawks Cruise Past Heat
headline.print_headline: Knicks’ Playoff Hopes End as Hawks Cruise Past Heat

docs.snippet: Can Henk Ovink sell Americans on a new approach to flooding — letting the water in?...
docs.lead_paragraph: Can Henk Ovink sell Americans on a new approach to flooding — letting the water in?
docs.abstract: Henk Ovink, former Dutch official who is now working at United States Dept of Housing and Urban Development, is architect behind department's push to address effects of changing sea levels on America's coasts; issue grew more urgent in wake of Hurricane Sandy; Ovink, who pioneered strategy of allowing flood waters to flow freely in the Netherlands rather than keeping them out, faces both cultural and logistical obstacles in translating his vision to the United States.

headline.main: How to Think Like the Dutch in a Post-Sandy World
